721921f-a.title: Manhattan: New Street - Wall Street
721921f-a.text:
VAICR AELEASE DWE
Wide World Photo: Please "'atch Credit
Main Caption for Picthree A82918, k829151and k796402
NOW Y0RN CII PiDI YEAES AG0 IN IRE MIDDLE
OP TRE GEAIBLIE2A20
New York, N.Y. - Fifty years ago on March 13 New York wss paralyzed by the worst storm in its history--the blizzard of '88. It had snowed steadily for twenty-four hours on March 12, and the snow continued to fall on the 13th, while the temperature dropped to four degrees below zero and the wind rose to a velocity of eighty-four miles an hour. It was estimated that the storm took a toll of 400 1ives and 920,000,000 in property dage. The complex life of the city was at a complete standstill for two days. Ihawing temperatures on March 14 aided in the slow task of digging out, which continued for several days. There were countless freak consequences of the storm, such as the sending of messages from Boston to New York by way of London, because all land telegraph service was disrupted, but the submarine cables were undisturbed. The average fall of snow was three feet four inches, but the high winds piled the drifts up to second-story window levels in msny places.
Three scenes from the blizzard are sent you.
R-3938 (G)
(Special feature layout for release March 13)
Wide World Photo: Please Watch Credit
829148 - Please See Main Caption Above
NOV Y0Y CII PiDI EASSAGO IN TRC MIODLE
OE TEO EAIBLIE2A0
New York, N.Y. - This photograph was taken after the storm had subsided and shows New Street, looking toward Wall Street.
N-3Y938 (S)

721922f-a.title: Manhattan: New Street - Wall Street
721922f-a.text:
New Street, west side, south from Wall Street.
July 26, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
721922f-a.folder: New Street & Wall Street, Manhattan, NY

721923f-a.title: Manhattan: New Street - Wall Street
721923f-a.text:
(1)
New Street, east side, north from but not including Exchange Place, to and including Wall Street. The clearing from Wall to Pine Streets, is the site for the new addition to the Bankers Trust Company.
July 26, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
New Street, north from Exchange Place as seen from the roof of 50 Broad Street, and showing only the upper reaches of buildings. On the left appears the Columbia Trust Company Building with the lofty Irving Trust Company Boilding overshadowing same. Pyramidal structure on the right
is atop the Bankers Trust Building.
September 16, 1931.
P.  '. Sperr.  NO REPRODUCTIONS.

723843f.title: Manhattan: Wall Street - New Street
723843f.text:
9-11 Wall Street (left) at the S.E. corner of New Street (right) showing the 18-story Mortimer Building under demolition. The New York Stock Exchange which is shown encircling this doomed edifice, will erect a 22-story addition here; this fnrming the northwesterly corner of same.
This set consists of a negative and a positive.
Between 1916 and 1922.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.
